title: A Randomized, Double-Blind,Placebo-Controlled Evaluation of the Safety and Efficacy of Neramexane Monotherapy in Patients With Moderate to Severe Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type
description_brief: Memory loss and difficulties with thinking associated with Alzheimer's disease may be due to chronic release of a brain chemical called glutamate. Glutamate helps transmit messages between nerve cells through interaction with a certain type of receptor (N-methyl-D-aspartate, NMDA) on the cell. Neramexane is a new drug that blocks the effects of excessive glutamate at the receptor (NMDA receptor antagonist).
drug: Neramexane (non‑competitive NMDA receptor antagonist — small molecule)
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests neramexane, described as blocking excessive glutamate at the NMDA receptor (an approach to reduce excitotoxicity thought to contribute to Alzheimer’s pathology). Neramexane is a small‑molecule, non‑competitive NMDA receptor antagonist, which indicates it targets a disease‑related neurochemical mechanism rather than being a biologic or purely symptomatic behavioral intervention. citeturn0search2turn0search8.

Act: Key extracted details — drug name: neramexane; drug type: small molecule NMDA receptor antagonist (open‑channel/non‑competitive blocker); trial design: randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled monotherapy in moderate–severe Alzheimer’s dementia. Clinical development entries list this Phase III evaluation. These sources support the drug identity, mechanism, and that it was studied as a therapeutic small molecule for AD. citeturn0search4turn0search2turn0search8.

Reflect: Classification check — under the provided category definitions, neramexane best fits 'Disease-targeted small molecule' because it is a small molecule designed to modulate a pathophysiologic process (glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity via NMDA receptors) implicated in AD. Note ambiguity: NMDA antagonists (e.g., memantine) are often used for symptomatic cognitive benefit, so one could alternatively label such agents as 'cognitive enhancers' if emphasizing symptomatic improvement. However, given the mechanism targets a disease process (excitotoxicity) and the developer category definitions, 'Disease-targeted small molecule' is the most appropriate classification. citeturn0search7turn0search5.
Web search results (selected supporting sources): PubMed pharmacology study confirming neramexane is a non‑competitive NMDA antagonist. citeturn0search2.
Web search results (selected supporting sources): Preclinical and comparative studies showing memantine and neramexane effects on memory and development for AD indication. citeturn0search8.

Web search results (selected supporting sources): Clinical trial registry / drug development entry for the randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled evaluation of neramexane in moderate to severe Alzheimer’s dementia (Phase III completed entry). citeturn0search4.

Web search results (selected supporting sources): Clinical study of neramexane in other indications (tinnitus) demonstrating clinical testing and tolerability of the compound. citeturn0search0turn0search6.
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention (neramexane) is a small‑molecule, non‑competitive/open‑channel NMDA receptor antagonist that blocks excessive glutamate-mediated NMDA receptor activation (excitotoxicity). NMDA receptors are neurotransmitter (glutamate) receptors, so the trial maps to the Neurotransmitter Receptors CADRO category. citeturn0search2turn0search1turn0search5.

Act: Extracted details — drug: neramexane (MRZ 2/579); mechanism: moderate‑affinity, voltage‑dependent, uncompetitive/open‑channel NMDA receptor antagonist (also reported to affect alpha9alpha10 nicotinic receptors); trial design: randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled monotherapy for moderate–severe Alzheimer’s disease (Phase II/III/III listings). Sources documenting drug identity/mechanism and the specific AD trial are cited. citeturn0search2turn0search1turn0search6turn0search4.

Reflect: The CADRO classification that fits best is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors because the primary molecular target is the NMDA glutamate receptor (a neurotransmitter receptor). Although NMDA antagonists can produce symptomatic cognitive/behavioral effects (e.g., memantine), the mechanism is clearly receptor‑based rather than, for example, amyloid, tau, inflammation or a non‑therapeutic diagnostic. If the trial had targeted multiple unrelated mechanisms primarily, R) Multi‑target would be considered, but here the principal target is the NMDA receptor. citeturn0search5turn0search2.
